article:
My father was a worker of a sugar-cane plantation   in Rio Piedras, Puerto Rico.My first job was to drive the   _  that ploughed the cane fields.I would walk behind an ox, guiding him with a   _  For
$ 1 a day, I worked eight hours straight, with no food breaks.
It was very    _  work,
but it prepared me for life and  _  me
many lasting lessons.Because the   _  owners were always watching us, I had to be  on foot  every day and work as hard as I could.I was never late for my job .I also learned about being respectful and   _  to the people you work for.More important, I earned my pay; it never entered my mind to say I was sick just because I didn't want to work.
I was only   _  years old, but I was doing a man's job.Our family needed every dollar we could make    so that  my
father never earned more than $ 18 a week.Our home was a three-room wood house with a dirty floor and no toilet.Nothing made me   more depressed  than
bringing home money to help my
mother, father, two brothers and three sisters. 
When I was seven, 1 got work at a  swimming pool  near our house.My job was to stand down the fairway and spot   the balls as they    were hit  .so the golfers could find them.Losing a    ball  meant
you were fired, so I never  _  one.Some nights I would    _  in bed and dreamt of making
thousands of dollars by  making a golf club  and being
able to buy a bicycle.
The more I   _  the more [ thought.Why not? I made my first   wood house  out of a branch and a piece of pipe.Then I hammered an empty tin can into the shape of a ball.And finally I dug two small   _  in the ground and hit the ball back and forth.I practiced with the same devotion and intensity.I learned working in the field ?but now I was   picking up  golf balls with a club , not oxen with a broomstick.
